132D953970164F22932CD28B96A0D98B.description: Recite poems, selections from speeches, or dramatic soliloquies with attention to performance details to achieve clarity, force, and aesthetic effect and to demonstrate an under- standing of the meaning (e.g., Hamlet's soliloquy "To Be or Not to Be").

C1316A7A87514E18801EED7A0E21062E.description: Test the audience's response and revise the presentation accordingly.

0DE6453BC22D4EBFBDCA93E348D3930C.description: Use the selected media skillfully, editing appropriately and monitoring for quality.

1599E96DCCC246B38BD049ABC29AD92B.description: Select an appropriate medium for each element of the presentation.

B5DCFADC7A3C46FD9BD77FCC6FA880E9.description: Combine text, images, and sound by incorporating information from a wide range of media, including films, newspapers, magazines, CD-ROMs, online information, television, videos, and electronic media-generated images.

F0405861537D448CAF8D15F6ACEB1A8B.description:
Identify and assess the impact of perceived ambiguities, nuances, and complexities
within the text.

C048E192BAA045988529B5CEAA665FB8.description:
Demonstrate an awareness of the author's use of stylistic devices and an appreciation
of the effects created.

5875585A28C2457B9B759156E3EE3696.description:
Support important ideas and viewpoints through accurate and detailed references to
the text or to other works.

F69DBE4BFBAF4DE592FFCCD8C053050E.description:
Analyze the imagery, language, universal themes, and unique aspects of the text
through the use of rhetorical strategies (e.g., narration, description, persuasion,
exposition, a combination of those strategies).

14B603ADEA4144A8A12D44033F281A67.description:
Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the significant ideas of literary works
(e.g., make assertions about the text that are reasonable and supportable).

2A4B695DF221404A884B91C082AA86C7.description: Include information on all relevant perspectives and consider the validity and reliability of sources.

450A351B28F342BA8087B1774453BF79.description: Explain the perceived reason or reasons for the similarities and differences by using information derived from primary and secondary sources to support or enhance the presentation.

69B919165C8C4B04B67C066DB3CC18CB.description: Analyze several historical records of a single event, examining critical relationships between elements of the research topic.

4DEEAB863AB74472B44588E2EB022067.description: Use exposition, narration, description, persuasion, or some combination of those to support the thesis.

447E8BFE9EA3494E9C60C3849F35034B.description: Deliver oral reports on historical investigations:

5517B4BE06344A1E952B6C02604967AB.description: Maintain a balance between describing the incident and relating it to more general, abstract ideas.

7F0AA7166564408D92E1F80DB99638F7.description: Draw comparisons between the specific incident and broader themes that illustrate the speaker's beliefs or generalizations about life.

7886CCA534754B95BC23EF74A6590C36.description: Explore the significance of personal experiences, events, conditions, or concerns, using appropriate rhetorical strategies (e.g., narration, description, exposition, persuasion).

60B1554C774A4A3F9DB974226473AB23.description:
Using the speaking strategies of grades eleven and twelve outlined in Listening and
Speaking Standard 1.0, students:

15389F29A2CB4B08A840E5658EB02868.description: Students deliver polished formal and extemporaneous presentations that combine traditional rhetorical strategies of narration, exposition, persuasion, and description. Student speaking demonstrates a command of standard American English and the organizational and delivery strategies outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard 1.0.

4DE4984AE4BF488893E16ACF31EC193B.description: Analyze the techniques used in media messages for a particular audience and evaluate their effectiveness (e.g., Orson Welles' radio broadcast "War of the Worlds").

9BE21B2D44924620AA737749A3350A50.description: Analyze the four basic types of persuasive speech (i.e., propositions of fact, value, problem, or policy) and understand the similarities and differences in their patterns of organization and the use of persuasive language, reasoning, and proof.

E01E8EEA63E0457BAD032F5C210959E9.description: Identify logical fallacies used in oral addresses (e.g., attack ad hominem, false causality, red herring, overgeneralization, bandwagon effect).

F1BEF108D59340C6B1807F6ABA3046AE.description: Critique a speaker's diction and syntax in relation to the purpose of an oral communication and the impact the words may have on the audience.

073E2DCB719147A0AFDB92E7D89D81DF.description: Analysis and Evaluation of Oral and Media Communications

7C96E50B55674C73AE48B3F299E79FEA.description: Evaluate when to use different kinds of effects (e.g., visual, music, sound, graphics) to create effective productions.

0C349F4DD943457598489B2897079136.description: Use research and analysis to justify strategies for gesture, movement, and vocalization, including dialect, pronunciation, and enunciation.

4FC1BE9B96AF4262A2248975162C73BC.description: Use effective and interesting language, including:

C7BC6972C51F465780F99ABB6CDBABEC.description:
Use appropriate rehearsal strategies to pay attention to performance details, achieve
command of the text, and create skillful artistic staging.

1475D13F760B4714B651A890A99F0165.description: Use logical, ethical, and emotional appeals that enhance a specific tone and purpose.

754B1C6641F74BDD860F9B5CC6320475.description: Distinguish between and use various forms of classical and contemporary logical arguments, including:

0298BA289F4142E28FAEE0BB227C0BC3.description: Use rhetorical questions, parallel structure, concrete images, figurative language, characterization, irony, and dialogue to achieve clarity, force, and aesthetic effect.

F81FD79E521B43CBB6D67A602C22572A.description: Organization and Delivery of Oral Communication

BA9F485E32E744EA9740A450FE63D3C8.description:
Interpret and evaluate the various ways in which events are presented and information is
communicated by visual image makers (e.g., graphic artists, documentary filmmakers,
illustrators, news photographers).

1C55068C97814B5382647DE8DF1FF367.description: Analyze the impact of the media on the democratic process (e.g., exerting influence on elections, creating images of leaders, shaping attitudes) at the local, state, and national levels.

5C4A14063BB14142BE567BCF9526F3CB.description: Recognize strategies used by the media to inform, persuade, entertain, and transmit culture (e.g., advertisements; perpetuation of stereotypes; use of visual representations, special effects, language).

43C934BC2F434E6E8DF5FC53999FF70F.description: Students formulate adroit judgments about oral communication. They deliver focused and coherent presentations that convey clear and distinct perspectives and demonstrate solid reasoning. They use gestures, tone, and vocabulary tailored to the audience and purpose.

6AA566F116DC42E2AFDC37D5B08A0DB8.description: Reflect appropriate manuscript requirements in writing.

5F5BFA60139645C6BE1A7237994EBEFA.description: Produce legible work that shows accurate spelling and correct punctuation and capitalization.

E1BABD27F0A4476AB48154872EB22E22.description: Demonstrate control of grammar, diction, and paragraph and sentence structure and an understanding of English usage.

CB602EB783944F079A8848741FD722B7.description:
Written and Oral English Language Conventions
Students write and speak with a command of standard English conventions.

52C30459BA8848C5B1F0065F8E1B5C80.description: Written and Oral English Language Conventions

6082215ABD55457A9A0E43928F050ED5.description: WRITTEN AND ORAL ENGLISH LANGUAGE CONVENTIONS

75C9137C293F4E749A90DCF045D73921.description: Test the audience's response and revise the presentation accordingly.

0E1C6BCB5A06417B8460C968D48439E0.description: Use the selected media skillfully, editing appropriately and monitoring for quality.

90F8B1D85AA049AD9096CAF82270A55D.description: Select an appropriate medium for each element of the presentation.

0DE042724E774537AAD4FB746C60775B.description: Combine text, images, and sound and draw information from many sources (e.g., television broadcasts, videos, films, newspapers, magazines, CD-ROMs, the Internet, electronic media-generated images).

35C094F2C8E44479A0F3747CD23640D5.description:
Follow the conventional style for that type of document (e.g., resume, memorandum)
and use page formats, fonts, and spacing that contribute to the readability and impact
of the document.

151C31E51B22407BA163B3DD43F33217.description: Modify the tone to fit the purpose and audience.

3C298A8F30B04F81AF105402413A0DA0.description: Use varied levels, patterns, and types of language to achieve intended effects and aid comprehension.

E8D14E73A31243838E2B3E28DC1FFDBF.description: Provide clear and purposeful information and address the intended audience appropriately.

30D63AA36C724AA0AA2AB3CDC699C3BB.description: Include information from all relevant perspectives and take into consideration the validity and reliability of sources.

831DA65B203A46178E7FD4A8719E3753.description: Explain the perceived reason or reasons for the similarities and differences in historical records with information derived from primary and secondary sources to support or enhance the presentation.

7F12BFB914214782B4BD5354F3D120BC.description: Analyze several historical records of a single event, examining critical relationships between elements of the research topic.

77DA944FA72347AB8FA84EC15FBF1F4E.description: Use exposition, narration, description, argumentation, or some combination of rhetorical strategies to support the main proposition.

C19E53F313E340B3BA03F7A68C44FDC5.description: Maintain a balance in describing individual incidents and relate those incidents to more general and abstract ideas.

C10DEE3EDA8840E1B621CBFC7CD5F58F.description: Draw comparisons between specific incidents and broader themes that illustrate the writer's important beliefs or generalizations about life.

74DEACF48187470BA41F60E33F2430E5.description: Explore the significance of personal experiences, events, conditions, or concerns by using rhetorical strategies (e.g., narration, description, exposition, persuasion).

B77281E77A784B2FA382F4131FF45FC5.description:
Identify and assess the impact of perceived ambiguities, nuances, and complexities
within the text.

B11DCF2B6AA14EAAABFE73D6AA2868B2.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the author's use of stylistic devices and an appreciation of the effects created.

0CF8A38418B944D4AF614526AA4A09DF.description: Support important ideas and viewpoints through accurate and detailed references to the text and to other works.

09EEA143ECFC40189D2C6694202A39BD.description: Analyze the use of imagery, language, universal themes, and unique aspects of the text.

A086BC3A3F13456EBEC3FCBFD9526403.description: Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the significant ideas in works or passages.

468675E5BC774406BCC8AF8352263F1C.description: Make effective use of descriptions of appearance, images, shifting perspectives, and sensory details.

1AD3CEA938DE4760B9DC5025F78AFBEE.description: Pace the presentation of actions to accommodate temporal, spatial, and dramatic mood changes.

5E481D6607FD48B8BC06C3671B10E60C.description: Describe with concrete sensory details the sights, sounds, and smells of a scene and the specific actions, movements, gestures, and feelings of the characters; use interior monologue to depict the characters' feelings.

6109F551828A48F0AF528CF8CF4ECC88.description: Locate scenes and incidents in specific places.

47DF6B24DE554B38B3CD379A04AB08C3.description: Narrate a sequence of events and communicate their significance to the audience.

03B40D4459194E4BBAD8C088B9D99771.description: Write fictional, autobiographical, or biographical narratives:

85E7EDEF86CC4CB996886C345E988DD8.description:
Using the writing strategies of grades eleven and twelve outlined in Writing Standard
1.0, students:

9F060C65F3B44F6CB33B1A8A8BA358A1.description:
Students combine the rhetorical strategies of narration, exposition, persuasion, and description to produce texts of at least 1,500 words each. Student writing demonstrates
a command of standard American English and the research, organizational, and drafting strategies outlined in Writing Standard 1.0.

A40FE633B9AD4888954CD3D5F04F1025.description: Revise text to highlight the individual voice, improve sentence variety and style, and enhance subtlety of meaning and tone in ways that are consistent with the purpose, audience, and genre.

1154B39B4FDB4B42BA86F24092DCFF46.description: Integrate databases, graphics, and spreadsheets into word-processed documents.

DE4A196F30BA47E8A8E9FB8EBEABD558.description: Use systematic strategies to organize and record information (e.g., anecdotal scripting, annotated bibliographies).

158BE8A2CC8041FE84A3856774D34138.description: Develop presentations by using clear research questions and creative and critical research strategies (e.g., field studies, oral histories, interviews, experiments, electronic sources).

B03856F5FC354303BF4ED5E6EF0910D1.description: Use language in natural, fresh, and vivid ways to establish a specific tone.

A8C7AF10AE6547CE8DDE748EB3CDF247.description: Enhance meaning by employing rhetorical devices, including the extended use of parallelism, repetition, and analogy; the incorporation of visual aids (e.g., graphs, tables, pictures); and the issuance of a call for action.

FF932ACF697841E2B9419C0D0FC2E80B.description: Structure ideas and arguments in a sustained, persuasive, and sophisticated way and support them with precise and relevant examples.

182726461BB84DCBB4D2294B465C56AB.description: Use point of view, characterization, style (e.g., use of irony), and related elements for specific rhetorical and aesthetic purposes.

FA48EDD0E8294FEB9F0A246C3A61FFDE.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the elements of discourse (e.g., purpose, speaker, audience, form) when completing narrative, expository, persuasive, or descriptive writing assignments.

89383E6AC9864AF99596132BE257CB1D.description:
Students write coherent and focused texts that convey a well-defined perspective
and tightly reasoned argument. The writing demonstrates students' awareness of the
audience and purpose and progression through the stages of the writing process.

864337487ECB4A349B53B685DAAFCE81.description: Analyze the philosophical arguments presented in literary works to determine whether the authors' positions have contributed to the quality of each work and the credibility of the characters. (Philosophical approach)

6C371B2776D441B6B18E39B857D8550F.description: Analyze the clarity and consistency of political assumptions in a selection of literary works or essays on a topic (e.g., suffrage, women's role in organized labor). (Political approach)

DD62D108F9A8464B9AABAB1B81B7FBD1.description:
Evaluate the philosophical, political, religious, ethical, and social influences of the
historical period that shaped the characters, plots, and settings.

A055F1B1ED524BF693351E9ADAF15E22.description: Relate literary works and authors to the major themes and issues of their eras.

1F0A55CCCEF24F3C80C958AF4B63ADBD.description: Contrast the major literary forms, techniques, and characteristics of the major literary periods (e.g., Homeric Greece, medieval, romantic, neoclassic, modern).

D8F4065ACD34435CA002DD4903017175.description: Analyze recognized works of world literature from a variety of authors:

C1DBC4195FCB4B228BC42A84112F622E.description: Analyze the way in which authors through the centuries have used archetypes drawn from myth and tradition in literature, film, political speeches, and religious writings (e.g., how the archetypes of banishment from an ideal world may be used to interpret Shakespeare's tragedy Macbeth).

5DFCCC9B647D46BF904B0BF93DDAAEDE.description:
Evaluate the philosophical, political, religious, ethical, and social influences of the
historical period that shaped the characters, plots, and settings.

FAB863B0042E4486937CC8A69D9B0D13.description:
Contrast the major periods, themes, styles, and trends and describe how works by
members of different cultures relate to one another in each period.

B2624B71B3B14808A06E6FB02705BD30.description: Trace the development of American literature from the colonial period forward.

BCAAF4DE31E44B8E83FF91573600380A.description: Analyze recognized works of American literature representing a variety of genres and traditions:

16B97C6F47C642BBB976EB148E695B42.description: Analyze ways in which poets use imagery, personification, figures of speech, and sounds to evoke readers' emotions.

006EC73E584941B4BB38633F945D4775.description: Analyze the ways in which irony, tone, mood, the author's style, and the "sound" of language achieve specific rhetorical or aesthetic purposes or both.

800CEE54734643CC93846050EA183CCA.description: Analyze the way in which the theme or meaning of a selection represents a view or comment on life, using textual evidence to support the claim.

63F790224D4A4922A20CD3CF478CF27E.description: Analyze characteristics of subgenres (e.g., satire, parody, allegory, pastoral) that are used in poetry, prose, plays, novels, short stories, essays, and other basic genres.

26D5D9E3922648F8870BEB2544915F6D.description: Students read and respond to historically or culturally significant works of literature that reflect and enhance their studies of history and social science. They conduct in- depth analyses of recurrent themes. The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students.

C17A6045A3E94EDFBEA6A1ABB56A3135.description: Critique the power, validity, and truthfulness of arguments set forth in public documents; their appeal to both friendly and hostile audiences; and the extent to which the arguments anticipate and address reader concerns and counterclaims (e.g., appeal to reason, to authority, to pathos and emotion).

A0346E792BCF4A958EF913DEDCDAA531.description: Analyze an author's implicit and explicit philosophical assumptions and beliefs about a subject.

ED9C4F80B34242EC89454E50D5A4C38C.description: Make warranted and reasonable assertions about the author's arguments by using elements of the text to defend and clarify interpretations.

05F4F360F26B47EAB47843A87CEE75A0.description: Verify and clarify facts presented in other types of expository texts by using a variety of consumer, workplace, and public documents.

AF5BD54FFD8340168204619CF15A02C2.description: Analyze the way in which clarity of meaning is affected by the patterns of organization, hierarchical structures, repetition of the main ideas, syntax, and word choice in the text.

55430DADCAEF454A9D531E2FF2C12D61.description: Comprehension and Analysis of Grade-Level-Appropriate Text

7FA3DB7397E94AE2AE151F31B5292AD6.description: Analyze both the features and the rhetorical devices of different types of public documents (e.g., policy statements, speeches, debates, platforms) and the way in which authors use those features and devices.

930FC6A9A84347A9B0AB3F4F7EE4FF93.description:
Reading Comprehension (Focus on Informational Materials)
Students read and understand grade-level-appropriate material. They analyze the organizational patterns, arguments, and positions advanced. The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students. In addition, by grade twelve, students read two million words annually on their own, including a wide variety of classic and contemporary literature, magazines, newspapers, and online information.

1C4D21E0C969445589300C393F43A23E.description:
Discern the meaning of analogies encountered, analyzing specific comparisons as well as
relationships and inferences.

17DF1478A25A41CFB41FA93F39867207.description:
Apply knowledge of Greek, Latin, and Anglo-Saxon roots and affixes to draw inferences
concerning the meaning of scientific and mathematical terminology.

A20C48865A0E4AF180F23C05062B27E6.description: Trace the etymology of significant terms used in political science and history.

B3531CA2DF3C4BCA95B55287EF839E30.description:
Word Analysis, Fluency, and Systematic Vocabulary Development
Students apply their knowledge of word origins to determine the meaning of new words encountered in reading materials and use those words accurately.

BBFC2210EC2C4699A65FE60B2FF9ED51.description: Word Analysis, Fluency, and Systematic Vocabulary Development
